thread.title: Europe open: Equity markets steady as investors sift through earnings
thread.title_full: Europe open: Equity markets steady as investors sift through earnings

title: Europe open: Equity markets steady as investors sift through earnings
text:
24.75 +0.20 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - European stocks were steady in early trade following uninspiring sessions in the US and Asia, as investors turned their attention to another batch of corporate news. At 0905 BST, the benchmark Stoxx Europe 600 and France's CAC 40 were flat, while Germany's DAX was 0.1% lower. 
"Yet more disappointing earnings from the US and a slip in China's Manufacturing PMI has traders concerned that all is not well with the global economy," said Jonathan Sudaria, night dealer at London Capital Group . 
Stocks in Asia fell after the preliminary China Caixin purchasing managers index for July came in weaker than expected. It dropped to a 15-month low of 48.2, missing analysts' expectations for a reading of 49.7 and below the 50 mark that separates contraction from expansion. 
Earnings were in focus again as worries about Greece faded into the background - for now at least - with Athens due to resume talks with creditors over its third bailout. 
Shares (Frankfurt: DI6.F - news ) in Air France (Paris: FR 31122 - news ) - KLM (Shanghai: 600686.SS - news ) surged as investors welcomed revenue growth and news that it was still on track with its cost-cutting plans, despite the company reporting a fall in operating profit for the second quarter. 
French defence company Thales (Paris: FR0000121329 - news ) rose sharply after its first-half profit beat expectations. 
In London, publisher Pearson , which announced on Thursday that it has sold the Financial Times newspaper group to Nikkei for Â£844m, was in the black after raising its dividend. 
Vodafone was also on the front foot after saying it has made a good start to the year, with organic service revenue up 0.8% in the quarter ended 30 June as the European businesses return to growth and customer demand for 4G and data takes off. 
On the downside, German chemicals company BASF dropped into the red after its second-quarter earnings fell short of market expectations. 
Shares in temporary power provider Aggreko (LSE: AGK.L - news ) tumbled after it said its interim and full-year results are likely to miss market expectations, as a result of ongoing security challenges in Yemen and a further slowdown in its North American oil and gas related business.
